questionText: At 9:00 a.m. on Tuesday morning while at work, a 36-year-old woman presents with sudden focal neurological deficits. A STAT EEG is obtained (Fig. 4Q1). After reviewing the EEG you urge the team to:

options.text: Do a lumbar puncture; this EEG is highly suspicious for herpes encephalitis.
Call psychiatry; this EEG is normal.
Activate the stroke team and start mixing the TPA.
Get a urine toxicology; this woman has been doing drugs.

explanation: Sudden onset of focal deficits is almost always vascular—anosognosia (lack of awareness of deficit) further points to acute stroke. This EEG shows rhythmic delta indicative of acute ischemia; there are no LPDs or focal spikes suggesting encephalitis, so immediate stroke treatment is warranted.

questionText: A 64-year-old man with known multi-infarct dementia and a history of well-controlled seizures is admitted for altered mental status. An EEG is done (Fig. 4Q2). You conclude:

options.text: The EEG shows polymorphic slowing which is worse on the right. He must have more vascular burden on the right.
The EEG shows ongoing seizure activity and he should be urgently treated.
The shunt is failing; this EEG is consistent with raised intracranial pressure.
It would be prudent to start an ASM and continue video EEG monitoring.

explanation: This EEG shows diffuse slowing with maximal right-hemispheric involvement—consistent with recent seizures in a patient with vascular risk. Starting an anti-seizure medication (ASM) and monitoring is appropriate. The right-sided slowing is rhythmic (not polymorphic), and there are no clear ongoing ictal discharges or shunt-failure signs.

questionText: A 26-year-old woman presents with an episode of rising out-of-body sensation and confusion. After looking at the EEG (Fig. 4Q3) you are most suspicious that:

options.text: She has left hemispheric dysfunction; there is a sleep spindle better formed on the right.
The EEG is normal; it shows phantom spike-and-wave, a benign variant.
She may well have epilepsy.
She is having focal right-sided theta in N3 sleep, consistent with sleep-walking and requiring sleep-hygiene counseling.

explanation: The EEG shows a brief right-hemispheric ictal-appearing rhythm with sharp waves—highly suggestive of focal seizures. Sleep spindles are alpha-beta bursts, not sharp waves; phantom spike-wave is diffuse and benign.

questionText: You are asked to consult on a 28-year-old woman on the psychiatric ward with confusing features on her exam. After looking at her EEG (Fig. 4Q4) you:

options.text: Order a stat lithium level; this EEG represents lithium toxicity.
Transfer her to neurology.
Advise the psychiatrists to start lamotrigine 25 mg daily.
Note the normal vertex waves and suggest adding an antipsychotic.

explanation: This EEG shows frequent right frontotemporal sharp waves during sleep—classic for partial-onset seizures, which can mimic panic attacks or psychiatric symptoms. Neurology evaluation (and ASM initiation) takes priority over psychiatric management.

questionText: Figure 4Q5 shows sporadic epileptiform discharges characterized by spikes followed by slow waves. Which of the following is true?

options.text: These are vertex waves indicative of stage 1 sleep.
These are sporadic epileptiform discharges with a phase reversal at Cz.
This is a Cz electrode pop artifact.
This pattern is typical of benign neonatal sleep.

explanation: A clear phase reversal at the central (Cz) electrode, combined with the classic spike–slow-wave morphology, confirms these are true epileptiform discharges rather than artifact or benign sleep waves.
